Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which evidence from the passage best supports the claim that adequate sleep is essential to human health?

A.Choice: “'Amazingly enough, you can go much longer without food and drink than you can go without sleep.'”

Key.Rationale: The evidence leads students to conclude that sleep is more important than food and water, so it is essential.

B.Choice: “'But we do know that almost every species sleeps ...'”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the given claim.

C.Choice: “The body also secretes hormones during sleep, including growth hormones.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the given claim.

D.Choice: “Many school districts are starting to pay attention to sleep researchers and are shifting their start times ...”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the given claim.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Which detail from the passage best shows how popular beliefs about sleep can influence individuals?

A.Choice: “'Most people view sleepiness and sleep deprivation as a minor annoyance,' notes Mark Mahowald at the Minnesota Regional Sleep Disorders Center. 'You never brag about how much sleep you got.'”

Key.Rationale: This choice states the popular belief that “sleep deprivation [is] a minor annoyance,” so people “never brag about how much sleep” they get.

B.Choice: “'But if you're sleepy, you can't regulate your emotions,' says Mindell. 'You're going to burst out in tears, even [over] an embarrassing situation.'”

Key.Rationale: The effects of sleepiness are only described.

C.Choice: “There are many reasons why teens don't get enough sleep, and one of them is a relatively new development. When your parents were young, they might have read a book or watched television before trying to go to sleep.”

Key.Rationale: The effects of sleepiness are only described.

D.Choice: “Instead, try maintaining a reasonable, regular sleeping and waking schedule. And remember, sleep is not negotiable.”

Key.Rationale: This choice suggests maintaining a regular sleeping routine, which is not necessarily a popular belief.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“Sleep also affects the ability to regulate your mood. If someone says something mean to you and you've had enough sleep, you can probably brush it off.”
What is the meaning of the phrase “brush it off”?

A.Choice: blame a rude comment

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

B.Choice: think of a clever reply

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

C.Choice: ignore a bothersome issue

Key.Rationale: This choice shows that if people receive enough sleep, they are better able to control their moods.

D.Choice: behave in a predictable way

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative, connotative, or technical meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“With all the trendy 'high-energy' beverages and coffees out there right now, it's easy to get a caffeine overload, and that's not good for sleep.”
What is the impact of the use of the word “trendy” on the tone of the sentence?

A.Choice: It creates a dismissive tone.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not accurately describe the tone created in the sentence.

B.Choice: It suggests a shocked tone.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not accurately describe the tone created in the sentence.

C.Choice: It creates a doubtful tone.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not accurately describe the tone created in the sentence.

D.Choice: It suggests a disapproving tone.

Key.Rationale: The word “trendy” combined with the details “caffeine overload” and “not good for sleep” help create a disapproving tone toward “ 'high-energy' beverages and coffees.”

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“So what can you do if you're running a sleep d͟e͟f͟i͟c͟i͟t? 'The good news is that you only have to make up about a third of what you have lost to function and feel better,' says Mahowald.”
Which phrase from the sentences provides the best clue about the meaning of the word d͟e͟f͟i͟c͟i͟t?

A.Choice: “good news”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct meaning of “deficit.”

B.Choice: “about a third”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct meaning of “deficit.”

C.Choice: “what you have lost”

Key.Rationale: “What you have lost” provides context for the correct meaning of “deficit.”

D.Choice: “function and feel better”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct meaning of “deficit.”

Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the information in the bulleted list in the box following the passage help to reinforce the ideas in the passage?

A.Choice: by providing reasons for following the advice in the passage

Key.Rationale: The bulleted list does not reinforce this idea.

B.Choice: by repeating the key points that are made in the passage

Key.Rationale: The bulleted list does not reinforce this idea.

C.Choice: by listing opinions that challenge the facts in the passage

Key.Rationale: The bulleted list does not reinforce this idea.

D.Choice: by describing ways to address issues that are raised in the passage

Key.Rationale: The bulleted list gives suggestions on how to get a good night's sleep, which is a key idea in the passage.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What are two central ideas of the passage?

A.Choice: Most teenagers get too little sleep, and modern life can make it difficult to get sleep.

Key.Rationale: The passage focuses on teenagers getting too little sleep and modern life making it difficult to get sleep.

B.Choice: Most adults read before going to sleep, and most teenagers watch television before bed.

Key.Rationale: This choice provides key details that support the idea that modern life makes it difficult to get sleep.

C.Choice: Most teenagers use an alarm clock to wake up, and noise can prevent people from sleeping well.

Key.Rationale: This choice provides key details that support the idea that modern life makes it difficult to get sleep.

D.Choice: Most adults drink a lot of caffeine during the day, and most teenagers exercise too late at night.

Key.Rationale: This choice provides key details that support the idea that modern life makes it difficult to get sleep.

Content: What is the main way that these two central ideas are developed over the course of the passage? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: by making comparisons with past trends

Key.Rationale: This choice describes structures that do not support the two central ideas.

B.Choice: by citing relevant research and statistics

Key.Rationale: The passage includes information from a psychologist from Cornell, the National Sleep Foundation, Amy Wolfson's research at the College of Holy Cross, and other experts.

C.Choice: by combining facts with personal anecdotes

Key.Rationale: This choice describes structures that do not support the two central ideas.

D.Choice: by listing information in order of importance

Key.Rationale: This choice describes structures that do not support the two central ideas.

Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Which statement best describes the authors' purpose?

A.Choice: to explain to the reader the relationship between diet and sleep

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by details in the passage.

B.Choice: to inform the reader of the importance of getting enough sleep

Key.Rationale: The passage focuses on presenting information about the “importance of getting enough sleep.”

C.Choice: to explain to the reader the research about sleep and room temperature

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by details in the passage.

D.Choice: to inform the reader of the ability to make up hours of sleep on weekends

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by details in the passage.

Content: Which sentences from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “Sadly, sleep deprivation can cause serious problems.”

Key.Rationale: This choice explains the results of a lack of sleep.

B.Choice: “Grumpiness and irritability from sleep deprivation cause behavior problems at home and school.”

Key.Rationale: This choice explains the results of a lack of sleep.

C.Choice: “Many teens also drink too much caffeine to sleep well.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not provide support for the importance of getting enough sleep.

D.Choice: “Researchers also have found that biology plays a role in teens' sleep patterns.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not provide support for the importance of getting enough sleep.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Based on details in the rest of the poem, which word could replace b͟e͟r͟e͟f͟t in the first stanza and maintain the meaning of the line?

A.Choice: emptied

Key.Rationale: The phrases “wind came roaring,” “gave them quite a ride,” and “white snow came biting” help the reader conclude that the trees have been emptied of leaves.

B.Choice: cheated

Key.Rationale: The context provided in the stanza does not support this meanings.

C.Choice: spoiled

Key.Rationale: The context provided in the stanza does not support this meanings.

D.Choice: reminded

Key.Rationale: The context provided in the stanza does not support this meanings.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which feeling does the figurative language in the second stanza suggest?

A.Choice: delight

Key.Rationale: “Delight” is a positive emotion that is not supported by the figurative language.

B.Choice: resentment

Key.Rationale: The figurative language in the second stanza does not convey a feeling of “resentment.”

C.Choice: discomfort

Key.Rationale: “Like unearthly moans,” “piercing like a sword,” and “chilled your very bones” are phrases that create a feeling of “discomfort.”

D.Choice: appreciation

Key.Rationale: “Appreciation” is a positive emotion that is not supported by the figurative language.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read the stanza from the poem.

:box:“It seemed like only yesterday,
The trees were mauve and gold
And leaves were gently falling down,
The days were getting cold.”
Which inference about the speaker does the stanza most strongly support?

A.Choice: The speaker fears the approach of winter.

Key.Rationale: This choice is an inference that is not supported by the given stanza.

B.Choice: The speaker feels that time moves too quickly.

Key.Rationale: The word choice the speaker uses to describe the leaves describes time passing quickly.

C.Choice: The speaker admires the vibrant colors of autumn.

Key.Rationale: This choice is an inference that is not supported by the given stanza.

D.Choice: The speaker prefers calm weather over bad weather.

Key.Rationale: This choice is an inference that is not supported by the given stanza.

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: Read the lines from the poem.

:box:“Large flakes are falling from the sky
And slowly sail around.”
What is the impact of the alliteration on the lines?

A.Choice: It hints at the symbolic meaning the snowfall has for the speaker.

Key.Rationale: This idea is a misinterpretation of the alliteration.

B.Choice: It emphasizes the strong emotion in the snowfall imagery.

Key.Rationale: This idea is a misinterpretation of the alliteration.

C.Choice: It explains that the storm and snowfall are almost over.

Key.Rationale: This idea is a misinterpretation of the alliteration.

D.Choice: It highlights the soothing rhythm of a gentle snowfall.

Key.Rationale: “Flakes are falling” and “slowly sail” provide an image of the snow falling gently.

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: How does the poet develop the speaker's point of view about autumn and winter?

A.Choice: by reflecting on other experiences with storms

Key.Rationale: This choice is not reflected in the lines of the poem.

B.Choice: by explaining scientific reasons for the change in the seasons

Key.Rationale: This choice is not reflected in the lines of the poem.

C.Choice: by describing activities the speaker takes part in

Key.Rationale: This choice is not reflected in the lines of the poem.

D.Choice: by reflecting on sensory images the speaker experiences

Key.Rationale: Phrases such as “extremely loud,” “unearthly moans,” “piercing like a sword,” “chilled your very bones,” “biting at your face,” “stung your cold bare hands,” and “hard to see” all appeal to the senses.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story, drama, or poem interact (e.g., how the setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How does the plot of the poem shape the setting?

A.Choice: As the day progresses toward evening, the temperature of the setting drops.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the poem.

B.Choice: As the storm passes, the setting alters from a harsh landscape to a quiet landscape.

Key.Rationale: At the beginning of the poem, words such as “roaring,” “piercing,” “chilled,” “biting,” and “stung” suggest a harsh landscape. As the poem advances, words and phrases such as “gently,” “sailed,” “even keel,” “dying down,” “peace,” “softness,” and “blanket” suggest a quiet landscape.

C.Choice: As the speaker remembers autumn, the setting moves to the future.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the poem.

D.Choice: As the winds blow, the setting changes from a forest to a stream.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the poem.

Content: Which lines from the poem support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “White snow came biting at your face”

Key.Rationale: This choice suggests a harsh landscape by using the word “biting.

B.Choice: “The trees were mauve and gold”

Key.Rationale: This choice provides a description of the setting rather than show how the setting changes.

C.Choice: “Some bobbed and weaved in waters rough,”

Key.Rationale: This choice provides a description of the setting rather than show how the setting changes.

D.Choice: “The trees are covered all in white,”

Key.Rationale: This choice suggests a quieter landscape by describing the trees as being “covered all in white.”

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: The passage and the text box both discuss how Maria Anna and Wolfgang's parents helped the sister and brother develop as artists. Write an essay analyzing the importance of this support in helping Maria Anna and Wolfgang succeed. Use evidence from both the passage and the text box to support your response.

SubTopics: Recognize and correct vague pronouns (i.e., ones with unclear or ambiguous antecedents).
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:Gene Autry had many talents, and one of them was singing. He performed on the radio and on television, and he loved i͟t. He touched the lives of many of those w͟h͟o heard h͟i͟s songs. His fans knew h͟e was an honest, hardworking person.
Which underlined pronoun is vague or unclear and should be changed?

A.Choice: it

Key.Rationale: The “it” lacks a clear reference to what Gene Autry loved.

B.Choice: who

Key.Rationale: “Who” clearly refers to “those.”

C.Choice: his

Key.Rationale: “His” clearly refers to Gene Autry.

D.Choice: he

Key.Rationale: “He” clearly refers to Gene Autry.

SubTopics: Use punctuation to separate items in a series.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) The airport manager works hard to make sure the airport runs efficiently, smoothly, and with few problems for airline passengers. (2) Happy, helpful, and friendly airport employees greet passengers and direct them where to go. (3) Passengers wait to board their flights after they check their luggage, go through security, and make their way to their gates. (4) Then they can watch, airplanes take off, land, and taxi down the runway.
Which revision should be made to the paragraph?

A.Choice: Add a comma after r͟u͟n͟s in sentence 1.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 1 correctly uses commas to separate three items in a series.

B.Choice: Remove the comma after H͟a͟p͟p͟y in sentence 2.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 2 uses commas to correctly separate three adjectives in a series.

C.Choice: Add a comma after c͟h͟e͟c͟k in sentence 3.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 3 correctly uses commas to separate three predicates in a series.

D.Choice: Remove the comma after w͟a͟t͟c͟h in sentence 4.

Key.Rationale: In sentence 4, the comma after “watch” is unnecessary since “watch” is the verb of the sentence, not one of the items in a series.

SubTopics: Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) The saguaro cactus lives in the Sonoran Desert in southern Arizona and Mexico. (2) This plant is special because it grows nowhere else on Earth. (3) It is also special because it is the largest cactus in all of North America. (4) When it is young, the saguaro looks like a skinny pencil covered in sharp needle-like spines. (5) When the saguaro gets older, it starts to grow branches that resemble arms. (6) Some saguaros have been known to grow up to 20 arms!
Which revision that combines sentences 2 and 3 into one sentence best improves the style of the paragraph?

A.Choice: Being special, this plant grows nowhere else on Earth and is also the largest cactus in North America.

Key.Rationale: This choice combines the two sentences in a way that lacks clarity.

B.Choice: In North America, this special plant grows the largest of any cactus that grows nowhere else on Earth.

Key.Rationale: This choice combines the two sentences in a way that lacks clarity.

C.Choice: This plant is special because it grows nowhere else on Earth and is the largest cactus in North America.

Key.Rationale: This choice combines the ideas in sentences 2 and 3 in a clear and concise way.

D.Choice: It is also special because it grows nowhere else on Earth and is very large for a cactus in North America.

Key.Rationale: This choice combines the two sentences in a way that lacks conciseness.

SubTopics: Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) In the central area of Chile is a long river valley. (2) People who visit there are just really amazed by the really pretty views. (3) Some people head for the lakes to kick back or relax. (4) Others sit tight in the amazing forests.
Which sentence of the paragraph has a formal style?

A.Choice: sentence 1

Key.Rationale: This choice uses words to create a formal style.

B.Choice: sentence 2

Key.Rationale: This sentence contains an example of informal diction, such as “really.”

C.Choice: sentence 3

Key.Rationale: This sentence contains an example of informal diction, such as “kick back.”

D.Choice: sentence 4

Key.Rationale: This sentence contains an example of informal diction, such as “sit tight.”

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content:
:box:Some people believe that the age of the printed book should come to an end. Many people now download books to electronic devices. Some libraries even have these devices for their users to check out.

Write an argumentative essay for your teacher supporting your claim about whether electronic devices should replace printed books. Be sure to use reasons and evidence to develop your argument.
